p: Despite the sensitivity of amphibians to changes in climate, it has been difficult to make generalizations about the consequences of climate change because of species- and population-level differences in physiology, life history, and habitat use [ 27, 29]. Idiosyncratic responses to climate change are observed across many taxonomic groups [ 30], which make it difficult to predict amphibian responses to climate change and establish effective conservation strategies [ 31, 32]. Furthermore, there are considerable differences in how climate variables (temperature, precipitation, seasonal extremes) are changing at the local scale across different geographical regions as compared to trends at the global scale [ 33, 34]. Given the large inter-annual fluctuations that are observed in many amphibian populations, detecting population trends and their associated climatic drivers can be difficult without long-term data [ 1, 35, 36].
